author: Kristen Lepore
title: Free weekend? Corgis, craft beer and comedy horror
text:
5. Grand Ave Arts 
(Jeff Koons'"Tulips" are on display as part of the inaugural installation at The Broad. Photo: Maya Sugarman/KPCC) 
If you want to see The Broad before the end of the year but haven't reserved tickets, this is your chance. Grand Ave Arts is offering up a day of museum and theater hopping — at MOCA, Walt Disney Concert Hall and the L.A. Opera — with open rehearsals, architecture tours, museum exhibitions, food and drink, performances and kids film screenings. Plus — if you get there super early — you might just score walk-up tickets to the newly opened Broad. Meanwhile, Grand Park will kick off its annual Day of the Dead art. (More on that at number 6.) 
When: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday 
Where: Along Grand Avenue in downtown L.A. 
Price: Free 6. Noche de Ofrenda 
(This Día de Los Muertos altar in Grand Park, titled "Seekers and Dreamers," is dedicated to Leonard Luna III and Jose Estrada. Photo: Benjamin Brayfield) 
For a third year in a row, Grand Park will become the ceremonial grounds for a night honoring the dead. The park is partnering up with Self-Help Graphics, a non-profit visual arts center, for the celebration that will feature altars from community organizations, ceremonial dances, poetry, a theater performance and prayer. Everyone is welcome to bring offerings to an altar by master altar maker Ofelia Ezparza. 
On Saturday, you'll get to see some of the artists at work, Grand Park's program director Julia Diamond told KPCC. "This year, we have 50 art and altar installations, so people can really watch those come to life." If you can't make the ceremony, visit the altars all week long — they'll be on display through Nov. 2. 
When: 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday 
Where: Grand Park | MAP 7. Santa Anita Pumpkin Patch 
(Photo: TIM SLOAN/AFP/Getty Images) 
Nothing screams fall more than pumpkins do — and we're not talking pumpkin spiced anything here. With Halloween just around the corner and Thanksgiving not too far away, this weekend is perfect for some pumpkin pickin'. Santa Anita's pumpkin patch will include a family fun zone with face painting and inflatable jumpers — plus, a chance to meet Seabiscuit. (Word?) At the end of the day, the whole family can decide whether to carve your pumpkin or bake it. 
When: Noon Saturday 
Where: Santa Anita Park | MAP 
Price: $12.50 per person | Family Fun 4-Pack for $50 | Purchase here 8. Happy Harbor Halloween 
Once you've got the kids' costumes all figured out, head to Happy Harbor Halloween on Saturday for a parade. The family-friendly event will feature music, puppet shows, reptiles, arts and crafts, face painting, games and costume parades. The festivities will happen at two locations — Wilmington and San Pedro — and both have free parking. 
When: 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturday 
Where: Downtown Harbor | MAP | Wilmington Waterfront Park | MAP 
Price: Free
